conclusion: Gravity produces a vertical downward force on every object.
Objects A and B are airborne and positioned above objects C, D, E, and F.
As A and B descend, they make first contact with the top surfaces of C-D and E-F, respectively.
The normal forces from the tops of C-D and E-F counterbalance the weight of A and B, stopping their downward motion.
Provided the four supporting blocks are not pushed past their tipping points, no block will topple; A ends up resting like a beam across C-D and B rests across E-F.
If either pair of supports were too narrow or if A or B were placed off-centre, the corresponding supports would tip and the supported object would fall.
With the positions shown in the picture, each “beam” lands stably.
Because each pair of supports is wide enough to keep the beam-like object’s centre of mass above the base polygon of the supports, nothing tips over.
The system settles into a new static equilibrium: A on C-D and B on E-F.
